title: 1822-B
statement: B. Karina and Arraytime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputKarina has an array of $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, a_3, \\dots, a_n$$$. She loves multiplying numbers, so she decided that thebeautyof a pair of numbers is their product. And thebeautyof an array is the maximumbeautyof a pair ofadjacentelements in the array.For example, for $$$n = 4$$$, $$$a=[3, 5, 7, 4]$$$, thebeautyof the array is $$$\\max$$$($$$3 \\cdot 5$$$, $$$5 \\cdot 7$$$, $$$7 \\cdot 4$$$) = $$$\\max$$$($$$15$$$, $$$35$$$, $$$28$$$) = $$$35$$$.Karina wants her array to be asbeautifulas possible. In order to achieve her goal, she can remove some elements (possibly zero) from the array. After Karina removes all elements she wants to, the array must contain at least two elements.Unfortunately, Karina doesn't have enough time to do all her tasks, so she asks you to calculate the maximumbeautyof the array that she can get by removing any number of elements (possibly zero).InputThe first line of the input contains an integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases.The description of the test cases follows.The first line of a test case contains an integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the length of the array $$$a$$$.The second line of a test case contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, a_3, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$-10^9 \\le a_i \\le 10^9$$$) — the elements of the array $$$a$$$.The sum of all values of $$$n$$$ across all test cases does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputOutput $$$t$$$ integers, each of which is the answer to the corresponding test case — the maximumbeautyof the array that Karina can get.ExampleInput745 0 2 13-1 1 052 0 -1 -4 06-8 4 3 7 1 -960 3 -2 5 -4 -421000000000 9100000007-1 -7 -2 -5 -4 -6 -3Output10 0 4 72 16 910000000000000000 42NoteIn the first test case of the example, to get the maximum beauty, you need to remove the $$$2$$$-nd element.In the second and third test cases of the example, there is no need to remove any elements to achieve maximum beauty.In the fourth test case of the example, you need to leave only the first and last elements.

processed.result:
You are given an array of integers.  The "beauty" of the array is the largest product of any two adjacent elements in the array.  You can remove any number of elements from the array (including zero).  Find the maximum beauty of the array after removing elements. 

Input:

* The first line contains the number of test cases, $t$.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains the length of the array, $n$.
    * The second line contains $n$ integers, the elements of the array.

Output:

* For each test case, output the maximum beauty of the array.
Given a list of numbers, find the largest product of any two adjacent numbers in the list after you can remove any number of elements from the list (you must keep at least two elements).
